oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wingo Baptist Church: school building
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The white frame building features a gable roof and twelve windows on one side. A small gable-roofed shed shelters a cistern and likely a well. The school is located in front of what appears to be a farm field. A road, Wingo Circle, runs beside the building.

Wingo Missionary Baptist Church, located in Trezevant, Tennessee, dates back to 1874. Although the church's roots are in the late nineteenth century, its current building was constructed in the early 1960s. According to the church cornerstone, Caldonia Lodge No. 79 helped construct the present building. The rural church sits next to railroad tracks running parallel to Highway U.S. 79. A church cemetery, Wingo Chapel Cemetery, is located nearby and contains burials dating from the twentieth century. According to the fieldnotes, the church is associated with a Rosenwald school. The Wingo School, located in Carroll County, was a Rosenwald school built 1920-1921 that was "destroyed by wind storm on May 10, 1927." Another Wingo School existed by 1941. Based on photographic comparison and location, the building across Wingo Circle from Wingo Baptist Church appears to be the Wingo School. Photographs in the Fisk University Rosenwald database seem to confirm this.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American schools -- Tennessee; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
